page.title: 02Farming survey - Stambourne
page.content: With the co-operation of Toppesfield and Stambourne farmers,we undertook a farming survey.Of the 2145 acres sur- veyed,almost 1300 (60%) were used for wheat and a further 267 for other cereals.Oilseed rape accounted for 320 acres.Comparatively small quantities of peas and spring beans (40 and 96 acres respectively) were grown.The most unusual crop was lupins,grown for animal fodder.Practically all land is drained.Each farm had at least one combine harvester and from 2-8 tract- ors at a ratio of approx.1:100 acres. Stubble burning was less prevalent than previously but only one farmer had abandoned this completely. Two farmers kept a total of 40 beef cattle plus calves.There were only 76 acres of woodland.The largest farm employed 4 whole-time workers and the smallest was run by the farmer single-handed.
